newsitem.title: ITALY: FORECAST - Italian growth seen limited in 1997.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - Italian growth seen limited in 1997.

text.p: Italy's economy in 1997 will grow at a slower pace than expected with no signs of an upturn until the second half of the year, economists said.
A Reuter quarterly poll of 18 analysts showed average forecasts for real gross domestic product (GDP) growth of 1.2 percent against an estimate three months ago of 1.5 percent.
The government's official GDP growth target for 1997 is 2.0 percent following an expected 0.8 percent rise in 1996.

But on January 15 Labour Minister Tiziano Treu said GDP this year was seen growing between 1.2 and 1.5 percent. "I expect this year to be a year of recovery even if it won't be sparkling," he said without elaborating.
Bank of Italy governor Antonio Fazio has been even more pessimistic, saying: "Economic growth in 1997 will not be far from the unsatisfactory figure seen in 1996."
Latest official figures put third quarter 1996 annual growth at 0.7 percent.
Analysts polled said still depressed levels of private and public consumer demand would brake economic growth, while investment was seen increasing, although only modestly.

Italy's foreign trade balance was seen making a positive contribution with exports continuing to increase more than imports rise, while stocks after a strong drawdown last year would be built up again gradually.
"The cycle will be influenced by the European economic trend and in particular by the speed of the German locomotive," said Alfredo Granata, analyst at Banca di Roma.
All the economists surveyed said a boost to the economy from domestic demand would remain limited, leading to less growth in Italy's GDP than the European average.

"The one-off Eurotax this year will eat into disposable income and this will result in even less consumer demand," said Paolo Casadio, analyst at Credito Italiano. The Milan bank saw private consumer demand growing only 0.8 percent this year with public sector demand falling 0.3 percent.
Bank of America and DRI forecast private consumer demand growing 0.7 percent while Banca di Roma saw a 0.9 percent rise.
"Consumer confidence should improve, partly because taxpayers have had several months now to get grumbles over the Eurotax off their chests," said Banca di Roma's Granata.

The unpopular 12.5 trillion lire Eurotax, including a one-off 5.5 trillion levy on incomes, is one of the main planks of the 1997 budget aimed at keeping alive hopes of early membership of the single European currency.

Analysts' forecasts of investment levels varied. "In 1997 company profits will be in line with 1996. The brake on investment growth will come from high real interest rates," said Ottavio Ricchi of DRI who saw investments growing 3.1 percent against 1.6 percent in 1996.
Bank of America economist Bruno Rovelli said investments would be limited by "a continuing stagnating economy but also by bank rates which are not yet in line with market rates."

Casadio underlined the financing difficulties faced by small-to-medium-sized companies and noted 1996 profits were less than in past years. Credito Italiano did not expect investment growth to exceed 2.4 percent.

Forecasts were generally for healthy export growth. "Italian firms are very competitive," said Rovelli who saw 1997 exports growing 6.5 percent. Credito Italiano forecast 4.0 percent but DRI saw only 1.6 percent growth.
